summary: Background Actinobacillus pleuropneumoniae (APP) is one of the most important swine pathogens worldwide. we use an immunoproteomic approach to identify APP protein antigens that may elicit an immune response in serotype 1 naturally infected swine. the traditional chemically-[2,3], genetically-, and irradiation-inactivated whole cell vaccines used thus far have been shown to provide protection against a homologous challenge from APP. some cross-serovar protection has been achieved with live-attenuated vaccines of mutant strains of APP serovar 7 [5] and serovar 1 [6,7] further development of cross-serovar vaccines would benefit from a molecular understanding of serotype 1 naturally infected swine and serotype 1 virulent strain S259-immunized rabbits. this approach combines the specificity of antibody detection with the precision of mass spectral analysis [19] for identifying antigenic bacterial proteins. all identified protein spots were analyzed by MALDI-TOF MS. western blot analysis of proteins on 2DE gel as transferred to a PVDF membrane. primary antibodies were convalescent sera from swine naturally infected with APP serotype. digital images of the western blots and Ponceau S-stained membranes were compared with the 2DE gels. we found 42 immunoreactive protein spots that represented 32 different proteins. the identified spots were labeled on each gel gi|307246787 Outer membrane protein P5 38.778/9.51 39.2/9.52 39.2/9.56 39.2/9.62 26 (63%) 25 (76%) 30 (68%) OuterMembrane 10 260 262 289 APBs7 mowse score is the score based on the mowse algorithm in Mascot. single top ranking proteins identified for each spot are listed in the tables. a total of 42 immunoreactive spots, representing 32 different proteins from APP S259, were identified by western blot analysis with convalescent sera from swine and hyperimmune sera from rabbits. four of those proteins, ApxIIA (spot APs25,26), D15 (spot APs21,22), subunit NqrA (spot APr12), outer membrane protein P5 (spot APBs1,2,3,4,5,6, ribosomal subunit proteins L7/L12 (spot APr4) and pyruvate dehydrogenase subunit E1 (Spots APr10, 11) were identified as immunoreactive proteins in members of the Bacillus cereus group. the remaining 23 proteins identified in our study are being reported here as immunoreactive proteins for the first time. the reliability of our protein identification was confirmed by comparison of the experimental MW and pI values of the protein spots on the 2DE gels with the theoretical ones. the majority of the theoretical and experimental values matched well, though some discrepancies remained. amide adenine dinucleotide (NAD, Sinopharm, Shanghai, China) was added to the medium at a final concentration of 0.01%. cells were harvested by centrifugation at 10,000 g for 10 min at 4°C and washed three times with phosphate buffered saline (PBS) swine naturally infected with APP serotype 1 were screened by two steps. two doses of 1.0 109 cells/rabbit were administered by intramuscular injections with a 3-week interval. serum titers were evaluated with S259 whole cell ELISA. IEF was performed using the Ettan IPGphor 3 IEF system (GE Healthcare, Shanghai, China) with 13-cm (Immobiline DryStripk, pH 4-7; GE Healthcare, Shanghai, China) as well as 7-cm (Immobiline DryStrip, pH 7-11; GE Healthcare, Shanghai, China) immobilized pH gradient gel strips. each strip was loaded with 200 g and 100 g of protein. each IPG strip plus an SDS-PAGE molecular weight standard was loaded on a 12% polyacrylamide gel and sealed with 1% agarose. electrophoresis was performed at 15°C at an initial voltage of 110 V for 30 min, followed by 220 V until the tracking dye reached the gel bottom. each gel was run simultaneously, one for Coomassie G-250 stain and the other for western blot analysis. rabbit at room temperature for 1 h (1:10000 dilution with blocking buffer) then washed three times with TBST for 15 min per wash. the western blot was repeated three times for each sample. a total of 769 swine serum samples were collected from 29 herds in different provinces of china in 2009. a total of 769 swine serum samples were collected from 29 herds in different provinces of china in 2009. a total of 769 swine serum samples were collected from 29 herds in different provinces of china. swine were never immunized any vaccines against APP infection. rabbits were immunized with formaldehyde-inactivated APP S259 vaccine. swine were never immunized any vaccines against APP infection. precipitated protein was collected by centrifugation at 10,000 g for 10 min at 25°C. the final pellet was air-dried and washed twice with pre-chilled acetone. the supernatant was treated with a 2-D Clean-up Kit. each IPG strip was equilibrated for 15 min with 10 mg/ml DTT and 40 mg/ml iodoacetamide in equilibration buffer. electrophoresis was performed at 15°C at an initial voltage of 110 V for 30 min, followed by 220 V until the tracking dye reached the gel bottom. each gel was run simultaneously, one for Coomassie G-250 stain and the other for western blot analysis. membranes were digitally scanned with a Umax scanner (TE77, GE Healthcare, Shanghai, China) the membranes were blocked with 5% w/v skim milk in 50 mM Tris-HCl buffer (pH 7.4) containing 0.05% Tween 20 (TBST) for 2 h at room temperature. the blocked-membrane was then incubated with convalescent sera from swine or hyperimmune sera from rabbit at room temperature for 2 in MASCOT searches, protein scores > 83 were significant (p 0.05) the remaining proteins with scores 83 were either verified manually or rejected. authors declare that they have no competing interests. the immunoblot was used as the background layer and ponceaus S stain as the surface layer. the 0%, 20%, 40%, 60%, 80% and 100% transparency data are shown in A, B, C, D, E and F.
